intro.name: Red-crowned Cranes
intro.intro: The red-crowned crane is the most endangered species of cranes under State first-class protection. With profound cultural connotation in China, Japan and some other countries, it is an auspicious symbol.

feathers.title: Red Crown
feathers.text: Red crown refers to the bare red skin on the head, which will become brighter during the breeding season.

feathers.title: Feathers
feathers.text: The adult red-crowned crane is pure white on the whole, but the part above the neck is black, except for the occiput. Black flight feathers form the appearance of a black tail when folded, but the real tail feathers are white. Red-crowned cranes moult once a year after breeding. Almost all flights feathers fall off at the same time, so they temporarily lose their ability to fly.

feathers.title: Height and Weight
feathers.text: Red-crowned cranes are 150-158cm tall when standing. Their average body weight is the heaviest among the cranes, ranging from 4.8 kg to 10.5 kg. Male cranes are slightly heavier and larger than females.

feathers.title: Crane Dance
feathers.text: During their estrus in early April, male cranes actively court females. Stretching its neck and unfolding its wings, a male croons a song, which a willing female will echo loudly. Then, they sing, jump and dance towards each other. Once a pair succeeds in mating, they will live together until old age. Since ancient times, the antiphonal singing and dancing of red-crowned cranes in China, in particular in the northeast, is seen as an auspicious “crane dance”.

habitat.text:
Red-crowned cranes often walk round in pairs, kindred and small groups. In the migratory season and winter, several or dozens of “families” form larger groups.

Red-crowned cranes living in China migrate with the seasons. They move to open grasslands and wetlands in the northeast in spring and summer. They spend winter on the southeast coast and the lower reaches of the Yangtze River. They mainly live in swamps, rivers and rice fields, etc.

album.text: The largest breeding base of the Red Crowned Crane in China - Zhalong National Nature Reserve, Heilongjiang Province.
The Red Crowned Crane winters in Yancheng National Rare Bird Nature Reserve, Jiangsu Province.

protection.text: According to the main destination areas of red-crowned crane migration, the Chinese government approved the establishment of Heilongjiang Zalong National Nature Reserve in 1987 and Jiangsu Yancheng Wetland National Nature Reserve for Rare Birds in 1992. Since then, based on scientific research results, it has established a number of wetland nature reserves in the coastal areas along the migration route as a protective measure.
